head.title: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water; More Miles per Gallon

hedline.hl1: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water; More Miles per Gallon

block.p: ''America's Neck and a New Noose'' (editorial, Aug. 2) hits the nail on the head by stressing the crucial role energy efficiency can play in providing energy security. But the biggest step we can take to promote energy security in America is to pass legislation before Congress - S. 1224 by Senator Richard H. Bryan of Nevada - that would require automakers to improve fuel efficiency 40 percent by the year 2000.

The refusal of American car manufacturers to make fuel-efficient cars leaves us at the mercy of the volatile actions in the Middle East. Half the oil Americans use is imported, up from 28 percent in 1984. We import more oil than any other country, and almost half the oil we use goes into our cars and then, literally, up in smoke, contributing to air pollution and the impending global-warming crisis. It does not make sense to continue this dangerous reliance.

The Bryan bill would raise the fuel efficiency of cars to a technically feasible 40-miles-a-gallon average. The average car on the road today gets 18 miles a gallon and pumps 58 tons of carbon dioxide, the major global-warming gas, into the atmosphere over its lifetime. By 2001 the Bryan bill would save 49.1 billion gallons of fuel and prevent 483.5 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions.
Going farther on a gallon of gas will also lessen chances of oil spills, make drilling in our last wilderness areas unnecessary, save consumers money at the gas pump and reduce our trade deficit.
